properties.Name: Camp Wood
properties.Synopsis: Camp Wood, also known as Camp Dubois, was the expedition's home base for five months. Clark established the original campsite and served as camp director while Lewis procured supplies for the long, arduous journey ahead. The expedition departed Camp Wood on May 14th, 1804, in a keelboat and two pirogues, beginning their long venture up the Missouri River.
properties.Secondary Source: Ripley Hitchcock. The Lewis and Clark Expedition (Boston: Ginn & Company, 1905), p. 21.

properties.Name: Cupboard Creek
properties.Synopsis: Just a month after departing from Camp Wood, Lewis and Clark named their first geographical feature: Cupboard Creek. Clark chose the moniker of "Cupboard" because he thought that the mouth of the creek looked like a cupboard.
properties.Secondary Source: Rogers, Ann. Lewis and Clark in Missouri.  Columbia: University of Missouri Press, 2002.

properties.Name: Council Bluffs
properties.Synopsis: In present day Nebraska, over 400 miles away from Camp Dubois, a set of BRONZE statues stand to commemorate the historic meeting between the Lewis & Clark Expedition and the tribes of the Oto and the Missouri. The meeting occurred at the site of Council Bluffs. The Oto, part of the Southern Sioux tribes, resided along the Missouri River. Their livelihood was based mostly on hunting buffalo but they also farmed. Their huts were oven-shaped, earth-covered houses grouped into towns. Upon meeting them, Lewis remarked "Those two parts of nations, Ottos and Missouries[sic], now residing together is about 250 men". However, due to smallpox, this number represented only a fraction of what the population had once been. The diseases that had wiped out many Native Americans had severely depleted their numbers. The meeting at Council Bluffs involved several chief members of the tribes and the entire Lewis & Clark Expedition. During the council, the Native Americans were told they were the "children" of a new "great father" who would provide them with trade and protection in place of their unreliable commerce with the French and the Spanish. It was a speech Lewis would deliver to numerous tribes throughout the journey. As Roy Appleman wrote in his article "Lewis and Clark: The Route 160 Years Later," the meeting between the Oto and the Corps "was the first of many meetings with Western Indians" over the course of the expedition.
properties.Secondary Source: Gale, Kira. Lewis and Clark at Council Bluff, River Junction Press, 1999.

properties.Name: Punishment of Moses Reed
properties.Synopsis: On the night  of August 18, 1804, Moses Reed told the captains he left his knife at the previous night's campsite and set out as if to retrieve it. However, soon the members of the expedition learned that Reed had fled, and moreover, La Liberte, one of the engagés [explain this term?], had apparently left with him. Reed was apprehended after a 12-day pursuit and sentenced to 828 strokes.  But before the punishment could be administered, he was dismissed from the expedition and sent home.
properties.Secondary Source: Brandt, Anthony. "Decision Point: An Unexpected Fork in the Missouri River Presented a Monumental Challenge to the Leadership of Lewis and Clark.(Meriwether Lewis and William Clark)." American History 48, no. 5 (2013): 32-40.

properties.Name: Sergeant Charles Floyd Dies
properties.Synopsis: The risk of death to the members of the expedition would seem to be remarkably high. However, only one man died on the journey across the great West. Charles Floyd passed away on August 20th, 1804, not from any bear attack, drowning, or act of violence. His death was the result of appendicitis. However, this disease was not known to the people of this time period, so Floyd would have died even if he had remained back East. His body is buried on a bluff near present-day Sioux City.
properties.Secondary Source: Floyd, Charles, and Holmberg, James J. Exploring with Lewis and Clark : The 1804 Journal of Charles Floyd. Norman, Okla.: University of Oklahoma Press, 2004.

properties.Name: First Buffalo
properties.Synopsis: Private Joseph Field killed the expedition's first buffalo, a species already in decline on the plains.  Hunting was central to the Corps' survival and identity.  They hunted not just to acquire food, but also as part of a friendly competition for bragging rights.  They shot specimens to study and to practice their aim as well.  Thomas P. Slaughter argues that members of the expedition did not have the same spiritual relationship to animals as the Plains Indians among whom they traveled.
properties.Secondary Source: Slaughter, Thomas P.  Exploring Lewis and Clark: Reflections on Men and Wilderness.  New York: Alfred A. Knopf, 2003, p. 134-159.

properties.Name: First sighting of prairie dogs
properties.Synopsis: On September 7, 1804, Sergeant Patrick Gass noted in his journal that the expedition had come across "prairie dogs," which he described as "in size about that of the smallest species of domestic dog." Lewis and Clark both showed great interest in the creatures, and took the entire party to a nearby prairie dog village and endeavored for the rest of the day and into the evening to catch one by pouring water into their holes. Despite their prolonged efforts, the members of the expedition were only able to catch one prairie dog. Sergeant John Ordway also noted the capture of the prairie dog, describing it in more detail. He wrote that it was "about the size of a small dog and grayish in color," and that they resembled dogs almost completely except for the tail. A prairie dog was eventually captured and, as Ernest S. Osgood writes in his article "A Prairie Dog for Mr. Jefferson," great care was taken to ensure that this living specimen would make it to the president. The prairie dog stayed for several nights at the Executive Mansion, and Jefferson was "delighted with his visitor from the far West."
properties.Secondary Source: Osgood, Ernest S. "A Prairie Dog for Mr. Jefferson." Montana: The Magazine of Western History, Spring 1969.

properties.Name: Teton Confrontation
properties.Synopsis: One of the most important diplomatic missions assigned to Lewis & Clark by President Jefferson was to negotiate with the Sioux tribes. On September 23rd, 1804 Lewis & Clark were setting up camp when three Teton Sioux boys came across the river. Over the next few days members of the expedition and a larger number of Indians held council on a sandbar in the Bad River. Members of expedition went through their usual charades of presenting western medicine and military technologies to the Native Americans but things began to grow hostile. Eventually tensions erupted, resulting in the expedition representatives holding guns, surrounded by fierce warriors with their bows strung. Wary of violence, Clark and one of the chiefs, Black Buffalo, engaged in a tense conversation.
properties.Secondary Source: Ronda, James P. Lewis and Clark among the Indians.Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press, 1988.

properties.Name: Council with Teton Lakota Indians
properties.Synopsis: Several days after the Teton Council, negotiation conditions worsened. The expedition left, but as they  Sioux tribes. On September 23rd, 1804 Lewis & Clark  were  heading out to set  setting  up camp  they were offered  when three Teton  Sioux  women, a gesture by  boys came across  the  tribe in order to acknowledge  river. Over  the  importance  next few days members  of the  expedition. However, after spending some three days with  expedition and a larger number of Indians held council on a sandbar in  the  Teton Sioux they experienced trouble after  Bad River. Members of expedition went through  their  boat was damaged. The crisis with the boat  usual charades of presenting western medicine  and  the arrival of Brulé warriors, led  military technologies  to  another standoff with  the  Teton Sioux. However, neither Lewis & Clark nor Black Buffalo wished for the negotiations  Native Americans but things began  to  end  grow hostile. Eventually tensions erupted, resulting  in  the expedition representatives holding guns, surrounded by fierce warriors with their bows strung. Wary of  violence,  and they were able to diffuse the situation. Lewis &  Clark  left, unable to finish negotiations with  and one of  the  Sioux, who remained an obstacle for trade  chiefs, Black Buffalo, engaged  in  the Upper Missouri for some time. a tense conversation.

properties.Name: Encounter with Arikaras
properties.Synopsis: Lewis and Clark sought to build an alliance with agricultural Plains peoples like the Arikara and Mandans, trying to set them against the nomadic Sioux, as part of their effort to build a new American trade system in the Plains.  The Arikara were a semi-nomadic people who relied heavily on agriculture.  An early European botanist claimed he had not seen finer crops anywhere in America.
properties.Secondary Source: Ronda, James.  Lewis and Clark Among the Indians, Nebraska, 1984, p. 49.

properties.Name: Newman's Insubordination
properties.Synopsis: Private John Newman reached a breaking point on October 13, 1804 when he was charged with “mutinous expression” and sentenced to 75 lashes.  The whipping shocked the Arikara near Grand River, as public corporal punishment was unknown among most native American cultures.  Newman was discharged from the expedition and performed hard labor at Fort Mandan until he could return to the east.
properties.Secondary Source: http://lewisandclarktrail.com/courtmartial.htm

properties.Name: Encounter with Mandan and Hidatsa
properties.Synopsis: The expedition passed through an abandoned Hidatsa village and noted a lack of game along the river, indicating the presence of indigenous peoples. While resting on the banks of the Missouri River, they encountered a hunting party of Mandan tribal members and subsequently three Mandan lodges constructed on an island. After their troubles with the Sioux, Lewis and Clark were more eager than ever to promote an alliance between the Hidatsa, Arikaras, and Mandans. As Clarissa Confer argued in her article "The Beginning and the End: Lewis and Clark among the Upper Missouri River People," though, this type of promotion did not always actually create peace. Confer wrote "[tribal relations] were neither a simple nor a static situation and did not lend itself well to the monthlong study that the expedition usually gave to native issues."

properties.Name: Grand Council
properties.Synopsis: Lewis and Clark hosted a council near Mahawha of Hidatsa, Mandan, and Arikara chiefs.  Rough winds on the Missouri kept some representatives from attending, and the start of the meeting was delayed by a day.  Lewis and Clark used the council to convince the tribes to make peace, as a prelude to their acceptance of the "American Plan."  The tribes accepted the proposals, but the peace would not last.  Lewis and Clark failed to appreciate the complexities of intertribal dynamics in the region.

properties.Name: Council with Yankton Nakota
properties.Synopsis: After scouting a possible campsite for the winter, Clark met with several chiefs, one of a Mandan village, and the other from a Mockerson village. The Mandan Chief invited Captain Clark to return with him to the village for food and to smoke a peace pipe. Clark, finding none of the sites that he scouted sufficient for winter, accompanied the Chief back to the village.

properties.Name: Fort Mandan
properties.Synopsis: The expedition party constructed a winter fort in modern-day McLean County, North Dakota, where they gathered supplies and conducted diplomatic business with local indigenous peoples. Lewis and Clark encountered French fur trader Toussaint Charbonneau and Sacagawea here for the first time. They also acquired crucial information about western terrain from the Mandans and Hidatsa.
properties.Secondary Source: Ronda, p.

properties.Name: First Encounter with Toussaint Charbonneau and Sacagawea
properties.Synopsis: Lewis and Clark met Toussaint Charbonneau, a French-Canadian trapper who had lived in the region for 8 years, and an interpreter named René Jussome. Both were employed to help the expedition navigate the Great Plains.  Clark notes in his diary that this meeting was accompanied by two Indian women, one of whom was most likely Sacagawea, who was sixteen and pregnant.  Charbonneau had probably acquired her through gambling or barter when she was ten or twelve.  By spring the captains had agreed to let her accompany Charbonneau, hoping she might be of use if they encountered her native Shoshonis.
properties.Secondary Source: Howard, Harold P. Sacajawea. Norman, Oklahoma: University of Oklahoma Press, 1971, 15-20.

properties.Name: Setting a Bad Example
properties.Synopsis: At Fort Mandan, Thomas Howard decided to scale the wall of the fort. Upon seeing this, one of the Native Americans in the area tried to mimic him and climb the wall as well. Howard was tried in court for his action and sentenced to 50 lashes. This seems like an extreme punishment for something as simple as scaling a wall, but the people of the expedition were worried that if the Native Americans knew that the wall could be scaled that they would be in danger.  [delete??]
properties.Secondary Source: http://lewisandclarktrail.com/courtmartial.htm

properties.Name: Sacagawea Gives Birth
properties.Synopsis: On February 11th, after a long and difficult labor, Sacagawea gave birth to a son. The boy was named Jean Baptiste Charbonneau and nicknamed 'Pomp' (Shoshoni for 'first-born'.)
properties.Secondary Source: Howard, Harold P. Sacajawea. Norman, Oklahoma: University of Oklahoma Press, 1971.

properties.Name: Lewis' Newfoundland Dog
properties.Synopsis: No expedition is complete without the companionship of a large, black, furry water dog causing trouble everywhere he goes. Lewis was accompanied on his trip by a large Newfoundland dog, weighing 140 pounds, named Seaman.  On the journey he alternated between bravery and foolishness. He was big enough to kill an antelope swimming in the river and haul it in. Yet when he first met a harmless-looking beaver, he was badly bitten.

properties.Name: Lewis Kills His First Grizzly
properties.Synopsis: The expedition killed its first grizzly bear, firing ten shots before the 600-pound behemoth died.  The majority of the bears encountered to this point had been smaller and less threatening. By the end of their trip Lewis believed the expedition had been very lucky to not lose anyone to a grizzly bear. He wrote that "the hand of providence has been most wonderfully in our favor."  [this should be May 5?; also last two lines are almost identical to a website...]

properties.Name: White Pudding
properties.Synopsis: Charbonneau prepared a "boudin blanc" (white pudding) from a buffalo killed by Lewis.  Finding food was one of the expedition's chief daily challenges and in the buffalo country of the Great Plains they had frequent opportunity to feast. Adequate food supplies would dwindle as the expedition entered the mountains and flirted with starvation.
properties.Secondary Source: Furtwangler, Albert. Acts of Discovery : Visions of America in the Lewis and Clark Journals, p. 97.

properties.Name: Sacajawea's River
properties.Synopsis: On May 14th, a gust of wind suddenly struck the boats, leaving one three hundred yards away, lying on its side in the river. Supplies began floating downstream as Cruzatte and Charbonneau tried to right the boat.  Sacagawea, carrying her baby, calmly fished boxes of supplies and scientific equipment out of the river.  Without her, dozens of items would have been lost.  On May 20, a small tributary was named in Sacagawea's honor, in recognition of her efforts.
properties.Journal Entries: “The Indian woman, to whom I ascribe equal fortitude and resolution with any person on board at the time of the accident, caught and preserved most of the light articles which were washed overboard.”
properties.Secondary Source: Howard, Harold P. Sacajawea. Norman, Oklahoma: University of Oklahoma Press, 1971.

properties.Name: White Cliffs
properties.Synopsis: The expedition passed the White Cliffs of the Missouri, large sandstone formations visible from the river.

properties.Name: Marias River Intersection
properties.Synopsis: Arriving at the junction of the Missouri and Marias rivers, Lewis and Clark were not sure which way to turn.  After scouting parties explored each branch, the entire company believed the north fork was the Missouri, with the exception of Lewis and Clark.  But the captains agreed to compromise: they sent a small party along the south fork by land to Great Falls, which proved that was the true Missouri.

properties.Name: Portage around the Great Falls
properties.Synopsis: The expedition undertook an excruciating 18-mile trek around the Great Falls of the Missouri River. Lewis set out early in the morning with an advance party, crossing level plains before ordering his four companions to separate in search of game. Thus, he was alone—according to his journals—when he came across the breathtaking Great Falls of the Missouri River. Lewis was overwhelmed by the falls' beauty, describing them as "sublime," and longing for a means more apt than a journal entry through which to convey their impressiveness. After drawing a topographical sketch, Lewis bemoaned his inability to fully express the scene. "After wrighting this imperfect description I again viewed the falls and was so much disgusted by the imperfect idea it conveyed of the scene that I determined to draw my pen across it and begin again, but then I reflected that I could not perhaps succeed better than penning the first impressions of the mind." The expedition began a  hike around the falls, a reminder that they were now leaving plain country and beginning an intense ascent into the Rocky Mountains. Ellen Baumler writes of the Corps portage hike in her article "Lewis and Clark National Historic Landmarks in Montana," "the grueling eighteen-mile portage around the natural wonder was month long ordeal with many days in preparation, and eleven days in transit.
properties.Secondary Source: Furtwangler, Albert. Acts of Discovery : Visions of America in the Lewis and Clark Journals, p. 23

properties.Name: The Experiment
properties.Synopsis: Lewis carried with him a collapsable iron-frame boat to be used after the portage around Great Falls.  The men covered the frame in leather, but due to the absence of pine trees they couldn't make pitch to seal it.  Instead they used a combination of charcoal, beeswax, and buffalo tallow.  At its launch on July 9 the composition failed and the boat (nicknamed "The Experiment") sank.  The Corps had to build new dugout canoes instead.

properties.Name: In Search of the Shoshones
properties.Synopsis: Despite his blistered feet, Clark set off to make contact with the Shoshone, knowing the expedition would need help to cross the mountains looming before them.  Lewis would do the same...   Neither party brought along Sacagawea, believing they knew best how to communicate with Indians.

properties.Name: Lemhi Pass
properties.Synopsis: Lewis sent George Drouillard to find traces of indigenous horses. Lewis understood that Native Americans had inhabited the area for centuries and were therefore far more familiar with the land than the Corps of Discovery. Tracks led Lewis and his party to Lemhi Pass, which marks the Continental Divide. Climbing higher into the mountains, Lewis saw a river which he assumed to be the Columbia but was probably either the Snake or Salmon.

properties.Name: Sacagawea's Brother
properties.Synopsis: While hunting, George Drouillard encountered several Shoshone hunters. The expedition met with Shoshone tribal leaders, subsequently discovering that Shoshone Chief Cameahwait was Sacagawea's long-lost brother. As youth, they had been kidnapped by a Hidatsa raiding party together, but Cameahwait had escaped and rejoined the tribe while Sacagawea had not. Cameahwait provided the expedition with horses for an overland voyage across the Continental Divide, a journey unadvisable by water (the only alternative route). According to Stephen Ambrose's article "Immense Mountains to the West," Lewis had been with Cameahwait for several days before the arrival of Clark, Charbonneau, and Sacagawea. Upon seeing him, Sacagawea "began to stare at Cameahwait," before jumping up and proclaiming him to be her brother. Sacagawea's familial connections with the Shoshone proved helpful to the expedition, and Cameahwait also provided the instructions for how the Corps could pass through the Bitterroots.
properties.Secondary Source: Anderson, Irving W. "A Charbonneau Family Portrait," The American West, Vol. XVII, No. 2, Spring, 1980.

properties.Name: Crossing the Bitterroot Mountains
properties.Synopsis: The Corps of Discovery found themselves in the rugged, mountainous terrain of the Bitterroot Mountains. The expedition was forced to contend with treacherous trails, lost horses, and scarce game. They frequently became lost and faced significant fatigue, hunger, and low morale. However, Stephen Ambrose writes "much has been made of this pass, perhaps too much." Despite the hardships faced in crossing the Bitterroots, it was mostly a test of the leadership of a "physically tired and emotionally exhausted" Lewis.
properties.Secondary Source: Ambrose, Stephen E. "Immense Mountains to the West: Lewis and Clark Breech the Bitterroots," Montana: The Magazine of Western History, 45, no. 4, Winter 1995.

properties.Name: Weippe Prairie
properties.Synopsis: Clark made contact with the Nez Perce after emerging from the Rocky Mountains (Lolo Trail). The Nez Perce were a semi-nomadic, hunter-gatherer people who relied mostly on foraging. They were also known to be excellent fishers and were skilled in the art of boat making, a fact which would save the expedition later on in the journey.  After Clark made contact, the rest of the Corps followed two days later.
properties.Secondary Source: Ray, Verne F. Lewis and Clark and the Nez Perce Indians. Great Western Series ; No. 10. Washington, D.C.: Potomac Corral, the Westerners, 1971.

properties.Name: Woes of a Traveler
properties.Synopsis: In what have been described at the three worst weeks of the Lewis & Clark journey, the Lewis & Clark expedition was subject to what all travelers fear: traveler's diarrhea. After successful negotiations and marvelous feasts with the Nez Perce tribe, a large percentage of the Lewis & Clark expedition succumbed to debilitating diarrhea and horrendous gas pains. Lewis could not even bear to ride his horse even at a gentle trot, and the expedition slowed dramatically.  [delete?]
properties.Secondary Source: Ronda, James P. Lewis and Clark among the Indians.Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press, 1988. and Vastag B. Medicine on the Lewis and Clark Trail. JAMA. 2003;289(10):1227–1230. doi:10.1001/jama.289.10.1227

properties.Name: Canoe Camp
properties.Synopsis: Due to the illness the Expedition had succumbed to after the feast with the Nez Perce, the fate of the journey hung in the balance. With not enough men able to work, the task of building canoes to continue along the Clearwater River took ten days to complete before the men could be on their way. The expedition (using small axes) built 5 canoes out of Ponderosa pine for the journey to the Pacific.  The Nez Perce assisted the expedition in canoe building and accompanied them along the Clearwater River in order to be of assistance in serving as intermediaries between the explorers and the Sahaptian-speaking peoples. Without this assistance, the expedition may have ended here.

properties.Name: Clearwater River
properties.Synopsis: With many of the men finally in recovery, the expedition was able to continue. The group departed on the Clearwater River in five canoes that had been successfully built with the assistance of the Nez Perce. However, their assistance did not end there. The Corps was accompanied by two Nez Perce chiefs, Twisted Hair and Tetoharsky, who were instrumental in helping with translations on the later parts of the expedition.
properties.Secondary Source: Pinkham, Allen., Evans, Steven Ross, and Hoxie, Frederick E. Lewis and Clark among the Nez Perce : Strangers in the Land of the Nimiipuu. Ron Laycock Collection of Lewis and Clark Literature. Washburn, North Dakota: Dakota Institute Press of the Lewis & Clark Fort Mandan Foundation, 2013.

properties.Name: Mount Hood Sighting
properties.Synopsis: Lewis and Clark held a council with the local Walla Walla Indians. The expedition traded bells, knitting pins, and other items of little value for forty of the Walla Walla's dogs. This trade exemplifies the paternalism with which Lewis and Clark viewed indigenous Americans. Continuing along the banks of the Columbia River, the expedition observed tribal members catching and drying salmon. The salmon economy was integral to indigenous life and livelihood along the Snake and Columbia Rivers, as it was throughout much of the Pacific Northwest. Clark recorded seeing a conical, snow-covered mountain: this was most likely Mount Hood, one of Oregon's most iconic peaks.

properties.Name: Celilo Falls
properties.Synopsis: The expedition encountered a dangerous stretch of the Columbia that lasted through the Dalles. The rapids at Celilo Falls were an indigenous salmon fishery and the oldest continually inhabited community on the North American continent, drawing tribes from across Oregon and southern Washington. American Indians had fished Celilo Falls for ten thousand years; the falls were integral to the region's salmon economy and rich cultural life. Tribes held annual ceremonies celebrating the beginning of the yearly salmon run in the village on the Columbia's southern banks. The falls would be submerged in the 1950s, and the village inundated, following the construction of the Dalles Dam.

properties.Name: Portage over the Cascades of the Columbia
properties.Synopsis: The expedition portaged around the Cascades of the Columbia (Grand Shutes) and traveled seven miles through the Columbia River Gorge.

properties.Name: Ocean Sighting
properties.Synopsis: Clark mistakenly claimed in his journal to have seen the Pacific Ocean, but the expedition was still twenty miles away.  "Great joy in camp we are in View of the Ocian," he wrote.  They were in fact looking at Gray's Bay in the Columbia River estuary.

properties.Name: Minority Vote
properties.Synopsis: Camping near McKenzie Head, Lewis and Clark had to decide where to spend the winter.  The options were to stay where they were, to cross to the southern side of the river to look for a better spot, or to return to Celilo Falls.  Lewis and Clark agreed that the weather at the coast would be less severe, and elk might be more plentiful south of the river.  But they decided to put it to a vote, including the voices of York and Sacagawea. This is the first record of a slave, a woman, and a Native American being allowed to vote on a decision pertaining to the United States, rights that were not granted to the rest of the American population for over a century afterwards.
properties.Secondary Source: Ambrose, p. 316.

properties.Name: Fort Clatsop
properties.Synopsis: The expedition constructed Fort Clatsop on the south bank of the Columbia in order to weather the coastal winter, establishing an American presence by flying a flag over the fort. Louis R. Caywood describes the fort in his article "The Exploratory Excavation of Fort Clatsop," as consisting "of an enclosure seven rooms and a parade ground," that presumably "faced south, overlooking the river." Caywood details the importance of the fort in the preparations that had to be made for the return trip, like the boiling of sea water to bolster the Corps' supply of salt.
properties.Secondary Source: Karsmizki, Kenneth W. "Cartographic Representations: A Controversy in Mapping Lewis and Clark's Fort Clatsop." Oregon Historical Quarterly 105, no. 4 (2004): 568-87.  Dattilio, Daniel J.  Fort Clatsop: The Story Behind the Scenery. Las Vegas: KC Publications.  1986.

properties.Name: Winter Obstacle
properties.Synopsis: On December 16th 1805, the expedition encountered one of the worst winter days. Rain coupled with violent wind caused trees to be downed around them. Unequipped to deal with the weather the men spent these days huddled for warmth on the shores of the river, unable to paddle their canoes through the treacherous waves.  [delete?]
properties.Secondary Source: Ronda, James P. Lewis and Clark among the Indians.Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press, 1988.

properties.Name: Whale
properties.Synopsis: While making salt at the coast, Alexander Willard and Peter Wiser learned of a whale stranded on the beach to the south.  Once he heard the news, Clark led a party of twelve men to the coast, where they bought 300 pounds of blubber and a few gallons of oil from the Tillamook Indians.  The blubber was a key supplement to their winter food supplies.
